tabData.tagHTML: Jainism is a practical religion where daily rituals are interwoven into the life of a devotee. The ultimate goal is to purify the soul, which in its pure form has infinite perception, knowledge, vigor, and bliss. A worldly soul is covered with karmas, primarily due to Mithyätva (wrong faith) and the four passions known as Kashäy (anger, ego, deceit, and greed).

To free the soul, Tirthankars have expounded many methods, one of which is the daily practice of six essential rites, or Ävashyak. These practices help free the mind from attachment and hatred, fostering spiritual progress. While both Shvetämbar and Digambar traditions advocate for six essentials, the specific observances differ between them.

tabData.title: The Six Essentials of the Shvetämbar Tradition
tabData.description: These are the six obligatory duties a Shvetämbar Jain layperson is required to perform daily. Click on a card to flip it and see the meaning.

cards.back: To remain in a state of equanimity for 48 minutes, with an oath of non-violence.
To pray to and appreciate the qualities of the twenty-four Tirthankars.
To show devotion and service to Guru Mahäräj (ascetics).
To repent, reproach, and reflect upon past wrong thoughts, words, and deeds.
Non-attachment to the body by standing or sitting motionless and meditating for a set period.
Taking religious vows to renounce certain activities or foods for a set period to instill discipline.

tabData.title: Understanding Sämäyik - The Vow of Equanimity
tabData.description: Sämäyik is the process of enhancing the quality of equanimity and is considered the essence of a Tirthankar's teachings. No one can attain Moksh without its practice.

items.content: Sämäyik is the act of remaining calm and undisturbed, treating all living beings as equal to oneself. For a minimum duration of 48 minutes, a devotee renounces worldly activities and lives the life of an ascetic, controlling their mind, speech, and body. This ritual is essential for removing Mithyätva and Kashäy, which ultimately removes all Karma.

During Sämäyik, one should not think about worldly affairs. Instead, one meditates on key Sutras:
  • 'NÄ-HAM' (I am not that) - To detach from the body and worldly relationships.
  • 'SO-HAM' (I am that) - To reinforce identification with the soul's true qualities of infinite knowledge, vision, bliss, and power.

There are two types of Sämäyik:
  • Complete Sämäyik: This relates to monks and nuns who practice equanimity at all times, having taken a vow to remain in Sämäyik for their entire lives.
  • Partial Sämäyik: This is for lay people (Shrävaks and Shrävikäs) to learn gradual detachment. The minimum duration is 48 minutes.

tabData.title: Faults to be Avoided During Sämäyik
tabData.description: Jain scriptures describe 32 faults of the mind, speech, and body that one must avoid to perform Sämäyik correctly.

tabData.title: Understanding Pratikraman - The Path to Purity
tabData.description: Pratikraman is the most important of the six essentials. 'Prati' means 'back' and 'kraman' means 'to go,' so Pratikraman means to go back, reflect, and review.

items.content: It is a process of repentance and sincere confession for past sinful deeds, asking for forgiveness, and forgiving others. It helps stop the influx of new karma and allows us to shed old karma through penance. During Pratikraman, a layperson reflects on the 12 vows and repents for any minor violations (Atichar) committed knowingly or unknowingly.

It is recommended to do Pratikraman twice daily: Räi Pratikraman (morning) for sins of the night, and Devasi Pratikraman (evening) for sins of the day. If this isn't possible, there are special Pratikramans for every fortnight (Pakkhi), four months (Chaumäsi), and annually (Samvatsari). The Samvatsari Pratikraman, performed on the last day of Paryushan, is one that all Jains should strive to observe.

• Dravya Pratikraman (External): Performing the ritual just for show, confessing sins but readily committing them again. This is considered harmful as it deceives oneself.
  • Bhäv Pratikraman (Internal): Performing the ritual sincerely, which results in minimizing or eliminating sinful activities in real life. This is very useful for the purification of the soul.

tabData.title: Spiritual Meaning of Items for Sämäyik & Pratikraman
tabData.description: Certain items are used during these rituals, each with a practical and spiritual purpose.

items.content: A small whisk made of soft, white yarn strings attached to a wooden handle. It is used to gently clean a space before sitting to ensure no tiny living beings are harmed. Spiritually, it symbolizes non-violence and the cleansing of our soul from karmic particles.

A small mat, typically of white wool, to sit on. It insulates the body, preserving the spiritual energy generated during Sämäyik, and protects subtle living beings on the ground. The white color promotes peace.

A square piece of white cloth, folded and held over the mouth while reciting sutras. It serves multiple purposes: preventing harm to air micro-organisms from our warm breath, stopping saliva from falling on books, and reminding us to restrain our speech and speak humbly.

Represents the presence of a Guru. If a Guru is not physically present, a religious book with the Namokär Mahämantra is placed on a stand (Sapada). This helps one maintain discipline and develop humility.

tabData.title: The Six Essentials of the Digambar Tradition
tabData.description: The Digambar tradition's list of essentials emphasizes the popular aspects of ritual and constitutes the fundamental modes of religious expression for the laity.

cards.back: To pray and appreciate the qualities of the twenty-four Tirthankars.
Devotion and service to Guru Mahäräj (ascetics).
Self-restraint; to conduct the householder's life with self-discipline.
Penance or Austerities, which include Pratikraman, Pratyäkhyän, and Käyotsarg.
Charity - giving alms to mendicants and the needy.

tabData.title: A Closer Look at the Digambar Essentials
tabData.description: These six practices form the core of daily religious life for the Digambar Jain laity.

items.content: Dev Pujä is the worship of the supreme soul to purify thoughts and develop spiritual powers. Guru-upästi is venerating and serving saints, as well as one's mother, father, teachers, and elders to gain knowledge and ennoble one's life.

Swädhyäy means 'study of one's own self' ('Sva' + 'Adhyäya') and involves reading and reflecting on spiritual teachings to understand the soul. Sanyam is control over the sense organs, mind, speech, and passions like anger and greed.

Tap is austerity, such as fasting (Upaväs), which means 'to stay near' the soul. It also includes devotion to one's duty and rendering service to others. Dän is charity, offering one's possessions acquired through legitimate means to the deserving. The donation of knowledge is considered highly superior to the donation of money.
